entry.title: Activities in IYPT
entry.content:
I have been in a club about physics called IYPT since the new semester started. The project our group focus on is about hand helicopter,which is a big challenge for us.

刚入学就参加了叫作IYPT的物理社团。我们小组研究的主题是竹蜻蜓（手提直升机），对于我们来说是一个巨大的挑战。

*The theme is like this: a simple hand helicopter can be made by attaching rotor blades to one end of a vertical stick. The helicopter moves upwards when the stick is twisted at a high enough speed and let go. Investigate how the relevant parameters affect the lift-off and the maximum height.**

题目是这样的：一架简单的手提直升机可以通过将旋翼叶片固定在垂直杆的一端制作而成。当垂直杆以足够高的速度旋转时，松开手，手提直升机就会起飞。探究相关参数对起飞和飞行最大高度的影响。

All of our group member feel confused about the project when we first read it .The area it is involved is far beyond our level. we made a plan of clear division of work,then discussed the type of hand helicopter we should buy on the Internet. Later we searched essays in both Chinese and English ,most of them are written by college students,then learn the professional formula and words by ourselves. These work was all done in after-class time. Then in the club time of second week,we did a couple groups of contrastive experiment and got some useful data.

所有的组员都对这个课题感到无比困惑，因为它超出了我们的知识范围。很快我们做了详细的分工，然后讨论应该在网上买什么样类型的竹蜻蜓。然后我们又去搜索了大学生写的关于空气动力学的学术论文，并自学其中的专业公式和词汇。这些都是在课余时间做的事情。在第二次的社团课上，我们做了几组对比实验并得到了有用的数据。

These are the whole process since these two weeks. Although we did not do too much,but the confusion when first reading the theme is gone , and the experimental goal is more clearly .We all gain valuable experience –the awareness of the important of teamwork,for any wrong division of work will absolutely leads to failure.

这些是两周以来IYPT社团的进展。虽然工作量不是很大，但是看到课题时的一头雾水已经几乎消散，实验目标渐渐明晰。我们也从中得到了宝贵的经验——意识到了团队合作的重要，因为任何一个人工作量太大或者太小都会影响事情的成功与失败。

Hope my group will be success step by step.

希望我的小组一步步走向成功。

entry.title: British educational system
entry.content:
I did a research about British educational system recently. Here is my mind map for the research.

Here is my research.

Britain has a long history of educating. Its education system has undergone hundreds of years of evolution, which is quite complete and complex, and has great flexibility. Generally speaking, It is divided into three stages :Compulsory Education, Further Education, and Higher Education. The differences between Chinese and British education systems make it impossible for students of the two countries to match each other in terms of age and academic level. Therefore, when considering studying in the UK, Chinese students must fully understand the differences between the two education systems and accurately determine where their level is in the UK education system. In order to choose appropriate courses and arrange reasonable study plan according to their own characteristics.

\Compulsory Education**

●The first stage is from 5-7 years old called the kindergarten education.

●The second stage is from 7-11 years old called primary education.

●The third stage is from 11-16 years old called secondary education.

The period of compulsory education prescribed by law is between the ages of 5 and 16. School-age children must attend school, and the State is responsible for the necessary tuition fees, books and necessary supplies.

The GCSE is the diploma obtained after completing the last two years of Secondary Education. The number of Chinese students studying at GCSE is small, and is only suitable for students under 16.

\Methods of marking**

Grade A* (A good result of exceptional quality)

Grade A (The higher grades needed for further and higher education)

Grade B

Grade C

Grade D (Regarded as average grades-a good base from which to grow)

Grade E

Grade F (The lower, but still useful,grades of achievement )

Grade G

Ungraded (Unfortunately, no score )

●**The fourth stage (further education)**

16-18 years old is a senior middle school or college preparatory class, which is the transition period from middle school to university, also known as continuing education stage, mainly includes academic direction and career direction study. Students who complete the preparatory courses mainly take the General Certificate of Education (Advanced Level).In addition to take the GCE-A level, vocational school students take the GNVQ (General National Vocational Qualification).

\Further education**

Further education is the most exciting part of the UK education system. It is also a crucial stage for Chinese high school students to study in the UK. Students in further education generally fall between Grade 8 and Grade 9. It is divided into two systems: the academic route and the vocational route. Both systems are equally valued in Britain.

\Academic route:(A******-level**\)\

The full name is General Certificate of Education Advanced Level, which is an important stage of the academic course. There are more than 100 subjects in it. We tend to think of A-level as the basic course of university. Generally subjects are selected according to two principles, which are known as professional objective principle and proficiency principle.

\professional objective principle**

The three or four A-level subjects should be chosen around the major that the student wishes to study at undergraduate Level and his/her future career goals.

\proficiency principle**

A-level grades also determine where student gets into university, so make sure you take one or two subjects that you are good at.

\vocational route**

GNVQ is similar to the GCSE and A-level in the academic route. Students can arrange courses according to their own needs and interest,and can even work in the process of learning.

\The elective system**

The elective system is simple and is divided into three parts,the Foundation, the Intermidiate(is similar as 4 sessions in GCSE and generally takes one year to complete), the Advanced(is equal to 2 A-levels and generally takes two years t complete)

\Methods of marking**

Distinction =A/B

Merit=C

Pass=D/E

●**The fifth stage**

It is called the college education, generally from the age of 18. It takes 3-4 years (medical for 5 years)for undergraduate study to obtain a bachelor’s degree. A master’s degree usually lasts 1-2 years,and a doctor’s degree usually lasts 3-5 years.

\A bachelor’s degree**

Bachelor Degree includes BA-Bachelor of Art，BSc-Bachelor of Science，BEng-Bachelor of Engineering,LLB

\University of joint school**

It is similar to the situation in China where many universities have secondary schools attached to them. Joint schools are generally close in geographical location,usually located in the same city. The purpose of establishing joint schools is to complement each other in teaching facilities and curriculum arrangement.

entry.title: hornbill
entry.content:
The hornbill is a peculiar and rare bird. The hornbill has a large head, a narrow neck, broad wings and a long tail. Their feathers are brown or black, usually with vivid white markings. Their body length is about 70-120 cm, their mouth is as long as 35 cm, and a pair of big eyes with long thick eyelashes, which is rare among other birds. Its mouth is hollow, which makes it lighter but strong.

Most of them live in the rain forests of Africa and Asia, and use holes which are picked out by woodpeckers as nests They often feed on fruit and insects for food. Every spring , hornbill in pairs choose caves in tall tree trunks. Generally, each lays one to four eggs at a time. The general life expectancy is about 30-40 years old, The longest can reach 50 years old.

There are 45 species of hornbill worldwide. Most of China’s live in western and southern Yunnan and southern Guangxi. In Xishuangbanna, China, there is a rhinoceros hornbill, which has been listed as a second-class national protected animal.

The hornbills are closely related to humans. Nowadays, they are loved by Sarawak people. They are regarded as sacred birds by local people. They are also regarded as a god by the Iban people of Malaysia, who celebrate Hornbill Festival every year.

entry.title: koala bear
entry.content:
Koala bear is Australia’s unique rare original animals. In 1788, John Price became the first European to document the animal after Europeans first landed on the Australian continent. Koalas soon got their first scientific name Phascolarctos Cinereus in 1816. Their English name comes from an English word meaning “no water”, because they get 90 percent of the water from the eucalyptus.

Koalas are fat, and their hair was thick. The length of an adult koala is about 70-80 cm, and the weight is about 10 kilograms. Their noses are big and round. Their forelimbs have very strong claws, which help them climb well. The male koalas weigh 50 percent more than the female, having a relatively broad face and small ears. The baby koala is only 2 cm long and weighs 6 grams. They must remain in their mother’s pouch for six months before they are fully developed.

Koalas spend most of the time in trees and almost all of their life in eucalyptus trees. They sleep most of the day and the rest is spent sitting. They almost never drink water , and they feed on eucalyptus leaves, which they eat a lot and digest well. An adult koala eats about 500 grams of fresh leaves a day. Although there are more than 600 kinds of eucalyptus to choose from, koalas just feed on 30 of them.

Nowadays, human activities, forest fires and climate change are the main threats to koala. As a result of the loss of habitat, the difficulty of restoring burned forests, climate change and the disease, the population of Koala in Australia has declined significantly. They are included in IUCN Red List of Endangers Species.

entry.title: lemur
entry.content:
About 1,600,000 years ago, Madagascar was a part of African continent. As time flew, Madagascar left Africa. According to the record of fossil, the first lemur-like animal appeared on the African continent 600,000 years ago before entering Madagascar.

There are twenty types of lemurs on Madagascar island, and because of the difference of environment and climate, their characteristics are different. They are generally small, with a dog-like face and move like monkeys. Their fur is brown and gray. Most of the time, they are gentle, careful and have a specially long tail.

They like enjoying the warmth of the sun, and it turns out that they are afraid of coldness. They depend on fruit on the island, and they care nothing but their families. When they jump from a tree to the ground in order to escape from enemies or find food or other reasons, it can be distinguished from normal monkeys, for they bend their back first then jump during movement.

Thanks to their isolated environment on Madagascar and islands nearby, they live without dangerous enemies. However, human deforestation is the leading cause of the lemur’s survival crisis, which has reduced the amount of space of them by 90 percent. Despite the terrible conditions, and important scientific value, Lexus still remain one of the least understood animals in the world.

Lemurs are listed on the IUCN Red List and the Washington convention CITES appendix I level to protect animals.

entry.title: giraffes
entry.content:
Giraffes are the world’s tallest living land animals, standing up to 6 to 8 meters, weighing about 700 kilograms. Newborn cubs can be 1.5 meters tall.

Giraffes can’t live on grass, they can only live on leaves. Their tongue is long and can be used for feeding. They live in forests and were widely distributed in prehistoric times, even in China. They are found only in Africa, and there are two species remaining.

The long necks and long legs can help them get cool. They live in hot savanna, and due to their large surface, this is good for emission of heat. Their lung capacity is large, and this is good for taking fresh breath and scavenging. Because of their long legs, giraffes have difficulty in drinking water. Giraffes drink water by straddling their front legs or kneeling on the ground, and are easy to be attacked by other animals, so social giraffes tend not to drink together.

Giraffes don’t sleep too much, typically two hours a night, and sleep can sometimes put them at risk. Giraffes spend a full minute getting up from the ground, and this reduce their ability to escape during sleep.

Given that some giraffes are increasing, some are declining and some appear to be stable, the most useful and appropriate actions for giraffes will vary depending on ecological stability, national policies and legislation. In 2010, they were listed on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.

entry.title: apply for 2021FBLA Emerging Leaders Award

I filled out the entry form as soon as I read the email sent by FBLA about the Emerging Leaders Award. They sent the Leadership Profile after a few days and asked me to write two mini essay. self-motivation

I study in the A level center in the International department of Jinling High School. I am a hard-working girl and always manage to deal with problems well. Over two days, my group discussed international politics with students of my age from all over the world. The greatest feelings came when everyone had their eyes focused on me as I was delivering my speech. Although I was feeling nervous, a friendly smile from the chairman removed my feeling of tension and anxiety when I stood on the platform, talking about my personal suggestions to resolve the problems in the Mediterranean. In other parts of the meeting like formal and informal debate, I actively participated into it and provided several suggestions as a delegate of Nigeria. The final document finally came out with the efforts of many people, and the country I represented, Nigeria became one of the supported country. This activity was both exciting and challenging because I had the chance to debate topics in the adult world, and my voice would be heard because all of our suggestions will be given to the United Nations. It shows that whatever we do in this world will have an impact on the course of the world. Creative thinking, critical thinking, communication skills, research learning fit into the society where knowledge is constantly changing, renewing and developing. These can make us the power to change the world.

relationship building

I had always thought my communication skill is good enough to help me get along well with people I first work with until my English teacher asked me to work with a boy in my class and make a poster. At that time we were learning the words that describe the quality of people, so I chose a topic similar to it, and was pretty sure that I could learn more than books from that process. It turned out that it was true, and I actually learned something far more than I thought.

The boy was active and thoughtful, which I thought was fantastic because his creative mind may contribute a lot to our poster. The fact was I found myself couldn’t keep up with him as he always came up with suggestions of the illustration, but I wanted to focus on the paragraph first then use simple illustration that matched with the content. Grooved bit, egg candler, incubator tray, pencil, spirit burner, wax, 1 ml syringe, tweezer, bio-safety cabinet, incubators.

SPF chicken embryo, virus strain, alcohol cotton, iodine tincture cotton, 75% alcohol, etc.

The whole process of inoculation requires aseptic operation, and result of death 24 days after inoculation is not considered.

entry.title: lying flat
entry.content:
I read about a piece of news on New York Times, which caught my eyes and I wrote down my comments. Please click the link below for the news.

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/03/world/asia/china-slackers-tangping.html

Here is my comment.

It’s a common sight: as our teacher passes back our tests, students who tried their best and still failed lean back in their chairs, put their hands to their faces, and sigh that they’re going to lie flat and sleep forever. Then a few moments go by, they open their eyes, see their classmates still working away, sigh again, and get back to the grind.

For most of my friends in China, “tangping” is just an internet buzzword, a meme that we use to describe our plans whenever we work hard but don’t succeed. The more popular term is “neijuan,” which means “rolling inside,” or “involution.” It’s the yin to tangping’s yang. If lying flat means giving up the struggle, then involution means internalizing it, taking the cutthroat competition for limited resources and making it into a cutthroat competition with one’s self: working harder, sleeping less, giving up more, and always feeling like it’s still not enough.

As the competition grows fiercer, so do the consequences, which are felt unevenly across members of my generation. Every year, around the time that university entrance exams take place, we hear about another spate of high school suicides, students so involuted that they turned themselves inside out. This article reminded me that another way exists, even if I don’t feel like lying flat is a realistic option for me. The choice between rolling inward and rolling over isn’t much of a choice at all.

entry.title: summer school Day3
entry.content:
Today is the third day of global summer school organized by Imperial College. We spent the whole day studying cancer biology and infectious disease.

We firstly learned about cancer. It is an umbrella term that is given to a collection of related disease that are characterized by the formation of abnormal cells. Globally, it is estimated that just under 10 million people die from cancer every year, and it is the second most common cause of death. The human body consists of an estimated 37.2 trillion cells. In a healthy adult, around 242 billion cells are produced every day replacing the old ones, which die as a part of the well-regulated cell cycle. Cancer occurs when this orderly process is altered and cells start to grow and divide uncontrollably. In the majority of cases, these cells form a mass called a tumor, and it can form in almost any part of the body.

Although cancer can arise from a single abnormal cell, it is typically not a single mutation but rather a multistep process. Mutations in key molecular pathways can occur, and the accumulation of many mutations that build to create the final ‘cancer cell’. This is why most cancers are typically found at higher prevalence in older individuals. With an increasingly aging population this represents a significant healthcare burden.

The gragh below shows six key characters of hallmark of cancer.

The two-hit hypothesis.

What is the cause of cancer?

Approximately 15% of worldwide cancers are thought to be caused by viruses. Some examples include the Epstein-Barr Virus (Burkitts lymphoma) and hepatitis B/C virus (hepatocarcinoma).

Famously, the human papilloma virus(HPV) has been found to be the main cause of cervical cancer. Fortunately, whenever there is a virus, there is the potential for a vaccine.

For decades, scientists believed that bacteria couldn’t survive long term in the stomach as the environment was too hostile- we know differently know. Studies into the role of gut bacteria(microbiome) are everyday revealing the vital role these bacteria play in human health. One of the first bacteria to be identified was a special shaped bacteria, now called Helicobactor pylori. It was long believed that conditions such as stomach ulcers were caused purely by lifestyle factors such as stress or eating spicy foods. The discovery of H. pylori in 1984 by Barry Marshell, quickly led to recognition of the bacteria as being the primary cause of both ulcers and gastric cancer. It is estimated that around two out of every three people worldwide if infected with the bacteria. Most people have little to no symptoms as a result of the infection. However, gastric cancer being the 5th most commonly diagnosed cancer, and around 750,000 deaths annually.

In the next step, we learn the immune response. Here is the slide that briefly introduce this.

The immune system is consisted of several key components.

The slide shows the primary and secondary Lymphoid organs and immune cells location.

MSH II: professional antigen presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells.

MCH I: nucleated cells including antigen presenting cells.

Effect functions of B cells.

Why the immune system is unable to fight cancer? Tumor cells hijack the immune system, inducing inflammation and promoting tumorigenesis. Continuous activation of the immune system can cause exhaustion or anergy leading to the immune system inability to fight properly. In some instances, the immune system cannot detect tumor cells, because cells of the immune system and tumour cells do not cross paths. Frequent mutations do not allow a proper detection of the tumour by the immune system.

Here are types of antigens.

Native cytotoxic T cells reside in the secondary lymphoid organs.

Then we discussed about what aspect of the immune system we would modify to make the immune system more effective against tumor cells and explain why in the breakout room. I listened different ideas from my teammates, and was amazed by their creative and open thinking.

The slide shows the principle of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

Here is the introduction about how CAR-T cell therapy work.

The first lecture is clinical skills. The professor first introduce ABCDE principle. A stands for airway, because airway obstruction is a medical emergency. Doctors should judge whether the patients can talk, are they unconscious, do they need airway protection, is there any possibility of spinal injury and whether they can remove obstruction. The slide below shows the way to protect airway.

B stands for breathing. Breathing could be compromised because of life threatening conditions, and doctors should look, listen and feel for the general sigh of respiratory distress. The count respiratory rate should be 12-18 per minute.

C stands for circulation. Doctors should look at the hands and digits and judge whether they are blue or not, and assess capillary refill time should be less tan two seconds. The count pulse rate should be in normal range, which is 60-90 beat per minute.

D stands for disability. The pupillary reflex, level of consciousness, temperature, blood sugar and drug chart of patients should be checked.

E stands for exposure. That means doctors should check whether there is rash due to allergy, Pedal Edema, or DVT(deep vein thrombosis).

Then the professor show us the definition of professional world related to blood pressure. It is the force of blood pushing through the arteries. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) is the maximum pressure in the aorta at the end of systole(when blood is ejected into the arteries during contraction). Diastolic blood pressure(DBP) is the minimum pressure in the aorta at the end of diastole(between heartbeats when the heat is relaxed). When blood pressure is elevated, this is “hypertension” and leads to many complications. Moreover, high blood pressure may lead to serious complication like heart attack, stroke and kidney failure, but they can be treated with life style modification and drug.

entry.title: summer school Day7
entry.content:
Today is the seventh day of the summer school. We continued watching videos about identifying transgenes of drosophila melanogaster.

Here comes the fifth experiment, Genomic DNA Preparation.

For each sample, one adult fly is taken and placed in a 1.5ml Eppendorf tube(the tube is kept on ice to prevent the fly waking up).

To each tube ‘squishing buffer’(180ul, containing PBS + 100mm EDTA) is added.

To each tube RNase (20ul, 12.5ug/uL) is added.

Using a sterile white pestle the samples are vigorously homogenized.

Proteinase K(20 uL. Qiagen DNeasy Kit) is added by gently pipetting up and down before leaving for 2 min at room temperature.

Buffer AL(200uL, Qiagen DNeasy Kit) is added and mixed by gently pipetting up and down for 50 times using a 1000ul pipette(set to 200ul) fitted with a blue tip before heating the mixture for 10 mins(using a 56 degree centigrade heating block or water bath).

The mixture is cooled to room temperature and 100% ethanol(200ul) added with very gentle mixing applied using a blue tip fitted, 1000ul pipette(set to 300 ul) as before.

Spin columns are removed from their packaging and the entire solution from the previous step is added to each column.

The columns, together with the discard flow-through and collecting tube, are spun at 6000xg for 1 min in a centrifuge.

AW1 solution(500 ul) is added and spun at 6000xg for 1 min, flow-through in the collecting tube is discarded.

The column is removed and placed into a new collecting tube.

AW2 solution (500 ul) is added and spun at maximum speed for 3 min, the flowthrough in the collecting tube is discarded.

The spin column is transferred to a new 1.5 ml Eppendorf tube and AE buffer (200 ul) added before leaving at room temperature for 30 min. This time, the column and tube are spun at 6000xg for 1 min with the flow-through retained in the Eppendorf tube.

After searching on Google, we found that the main component of the squishing buffer is detergent.

The remaining strains are Dam and Gene X. The last experiment will help identify it.

The tube containing the PCR master mix is vortexed and spun.

Using a P20 pipette master mix(19ul) is pipetted into two separate PCR tubes. The master mix contains 2 sets of primers, one for Dam, and one for gene X.

Using either a P2 or P10 pipette, a sample of purified DNA (1 ul), from Expt 5 above, is pipetted into the corresponding tube containing PCR reaction mixture(19 ul)

The PCR reaction is conducted in a thermal cycler (set as ‘Fly PCR’ in the machine) according to the automated conditions.

I learned a lot about professional words in this area and saw how the machine worked during the process. The academic lecture is about to the end, and hopefully I can enjoy myself in the last three days.

entry.content:
Today is the sixth day of global summer school. We were told to watch videos about several experiments and identified transgenes of drosophila melanogaster. Five properties were given.

GFP - Expresses a protein cloned from a jellyfish, which is affected by ultraviolet light, in the fat body cells of the larvae.

lacZ – The lacZ gene from E.coli encodes beta-galactosidase, an enzyme that cleaves lactose into glucose and galactose.

Dam – Expresses the DNA adenine methyltransferase (Dam) protein from E.coli (when crossed to a GAL4 line) that allows researchers to study gene regulation and chromatin in Drosophila. The plasmid carrying this gene will amplify with primer pair1. It will give a 550 base pair product.

Dam-gene X– Expresses a protein fused to Dam(when crossed to a GAL4 line). This gene will amplify with primer pair 2. It will give a 400 base pair product.

Gene Y – Identified in a screen looking for thermosensitive behavioural phenotypes in drosophila. When expressed in neurons, it will exhibit a phenotype at warmer temperature(>=30 degree centigrade).

The first experiment is lacZ activity.

Firstly, retrieve a wandering L3 larva of each mystery genotype and place each one in a seperate 1.5ml tube. Wash once in cold in 700 ul of cold PBS, and then remove all the PBS and dispose of it in the waste pot.

Secondly, pipette 300 ul of 50 mm ONPG substrate solution into each tube. While transferring for each tube, without ejecting all liquid from the tip, repeatedly jab and crush the larva with the tip. Vortex mixer can be used to help.

Thirdly, eject the remaining liquid from the tip and mix well by pipetting up and down.

After a few minutes - appearance of yellow colouration for reaction mixture containing larva expressing lacZ.

The second experiment is LacZ Expression in Larvae.

A wandering L3 larva(identified in the first experiment) is retrieved and washed in cold PBS.

Of the given 0.2% X-gal straining solution, a droplet is pipetted onto a glass slide.

Larval tissues are dissected out using cold PBS(900ul) in a small petri dish (with a black Sylgard bottom) under a dissecting microscope.

The dissected tissues are transferred into the droplet of the X-gal staining solution on the glass slide.

Vaseline is applied to four points on the slide where the coverslip’s corners will be.

The coverslip is placed on the Vaseline, pushing down each corner individually until the coverslip is just in contact with the X-gal staining solution.

Staining room temperature is conducted over 20 mins.

As a result, a blue color is produced.

The third one is Fluorescence Analysis. A plate containing all strains of the larvae, a glass slide and some tweezers are taken to the fluorescence microscope.

On larvae from each strain is lined up on the slide before placing on the microscope to allow the different larvae to be compared side by side.

It is obvious to see which one is DFP positive.

The fourth experiment is thermosensitivity assay.

Vials containing adult flies are placed in a 37 degree centigrade water bath for 5 min.

For one vial, its contents are poured onto a dry ice-cooled platform to anaesthetise them.

The files are observed under the microscope to identify differences in the population.

Once any differences between the ones that were paralyzed and the ones that were not are identified, a brush is used to transfer one group into the original vial and the other into a new vial, thus separating them.

To check the hypothesis, all the flies are allowed to wake up and then both vials containing separated adult flies are placed into the 37 degree centigrade water bath, again for 5 min, nothing any dichotomy in the paralysis phenotype.

It is observed that one of the tube have flies that lie at the bottom, so the flies in that tube are separated according to the gender, and repeat the experiment. It turns out that only female flies are sensitive to the temperature while male are not.

The four experiments showed me the magic of changing variable during the process. It is the first time I fins this method efficient and time-saving.

entry.title: rank women by their looks
entry.content:
This news on New York Times reminded me of my own experience, then I wrote down a few comments.

Here is the news.https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/21/world/asia/china-artwork-ranking-women.html

When I was seven, my best friend told me that she was thinking of getting a chemical peel. I’d never heard of the procedure before, and when she explained it to me, I thought she must be joking. She wasn’t.

That was 8 years ago, about the same time that Song Ta first exhibited his video “Uglier and Uglier.” As Ms. Qin and Ms. Chien explain, Song “secretly filmed thousands of female students” at a Chinese university and then ranked them according to the order suggested by the title. Although the “artwork” passed mostly unnoticed then, Song’s piece is now getting the reception it deserves: condemnation and ridicule.

But even though this suggests that feminists are taking on an increasingly prominent role in China, I’m here to report that the more things change, the more they stay the same. Among my female classmates, appearance anxiety is as rampant as ever, and a recent push toward more “natural” beauty standards (including a move away from plastic surgery and even make-up) has made it all the more apparent that being beautiful still represents an incalculable boon to one’s fortunes, a winning ticket in the genetic lottery. And of course, this trend applies more to women, who are used to wearing make-up, than to men, who aren’t. While I’m glad that my country is beginning to recognize that looks aren’t everything, it looks like we still have a long way to go before we reach total equality.
